Tabs

Tab controls are used to divide the content of a single screen to several smaller parts. Tab controls do not act as a substitute for the navigation bar but they can be used to make a single screen easier to comprehend and use. Independent screens should always be presented in navigation bar.

  • The page content can be divided into several parallel groups that are logical parts of the whole. With tabs the user can focus on a single part instead of the complex whole.
  • The navigation order between the tabs is free and the tab contents are optional by nature.
  • Changing the information on one tab page does not affect the information on the other tabs or cause inconsistencies between tabs.
  • If a function requires going through all of the separate parts - even if the order is free - use a flow wizard instead, allowing the directed handling of all the parts.

Navs available in Bootstrap have shared markup, starting with the base .nav class, as well as shared states. Swap modifier classes to switch between each style.

Using navs for tab panels requires JavaScript tabs plugin

Rules and recommendations

Make sure that each tab's content forms a logical part of the view concept.

Place the most common part as a default tab (first tab on the left)

Disabled Tabs

For any nav component, add .disabled for gray links and no hover effects.

This class will only change the <a>'s appearance, not its functionality. Use custom JavaScript to disable links here.
